column2: formerly Fort Sibut (French: Fort-Sibut) is the capital of Kémo
column3: one of the 14 prefectures of the Central African Republic. An important transport hub
column4: it is situated 188 km (117 mi) north of the capital Bangui and is known for its market.

column1: Sibut is located at the Northern end of the paved road coming from the capital
column4: one going North to Kaga Bandoro
column5: and the other east towards Bomimi
column6: a thriving agricultural village of 450 people

column1: The town of Sibut sits on the banks of the Kémo
column2: a minor tributary of the Ubangi River about 150 km (93 mi) long. Formerly an important route of supply and communication between Fort de Possel on the Ubangi and the French settlements around Lake Chad
column3: the river is now non-navigable even with small watercraft.

column1: The present city has one high school which also serves as a landing strip
column2: and a market.  Local food in street cafes include gozo (cassava) and peanut spinach sauce
column3: along with various species of bushmeat.  Local drink includes palm wine and 33 beer. The Peace Corps had volunteers located in Sibut until the coup d'état of 1996.

column1: On 29 December 2012 the city was captured by Seleka rebels. On 2 February 2014 Anti-balaka took control of the city following Seleka withdrawal. In May 2018 Central African Armed Forces were redployed in the city with help of Russian instructors.
Köppen-Geiger climate classification system classifies its climate as tropical wet and dry (Aw).
